p: There has been a worldwide recent increase in non-communicable diseases such as obesity. The WHO established that a person is overweight when his/her body mass index (BMI, calculated as kg/m 2) is over or equal to 25 and obese when the BMI is equal to or more than 30 [ 17]. The global epidemic of obesity has been on the rise, mainly due to the worldwide change of diet and an increase in sedentary lifestyle [ 18]. It is reported that obesity cases almost tripled between 1989 and 2011 [ 17]. The WHO states that obesity is the seventh cause of death, and there are approximately 2.8 million people who die every year due to risk factors associated with being overweight or obese [ 17]. Obesity reduces life expectancy at the age of 40 by at least 7 years [ 19]. Recent statistics showed that in 2016, there were more than 1.9 billion adults who were overweight and 650 million people who were obese [ 17]. In 1998, a study indicated that about 21% of the South African population was obese [ 20]. Of the population, 57% of women and 29% of men were obese [ 21]. Furthermore, recent South African statistics show that there has been a rise of the number of obese or overweight people in the country: approximately two-thirds of South African women (68%) are obese or overweight, while 31% of men are reported to be obese [ 22].
